intro: Xanthogalum tatianae, commonly known as the Tatiana's ghostflower, is a rare and striking plant native to the arid regions of Mexico. It belongs to the Apocynaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and showy, often colorful flowers. The plant produces small, yellowish to orange flowers that bloom in the summer, attracting specific pollinators such as moths and bees. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered in fine hairs, adapted to reduce water loss in its harsh environment. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Xanthogalum tatianae is considered endangered and is of great interest to botanists and conservationists.
